title: Suzi Quatro: wild one or mild one?
text:
“I’m a Gemini,” she replies. The twins, the divided personality? “Everybody’s got two sides. But mine are very pronounced.”

In her autobiography Unzipped, she tells me, she wrote with two voices: “I found it easier to have ‘Little Suzi from Detroit’ speak, and 'Suzi Quatro' speak.”

Let’s start with Little Suzi. She was born into an Italian-American family (the surname was actually Quattrocchi – the more catchy abbreviation was reputedly coined by the immigration authorities). Her auto factory worker dad was also a musician, which he passed on to his six kids. Quatro began on drums and piano and picked up bass later.

In 1964, her older sister formed a pop quintet called the Pleasure Seekers with two friends and two sisters, in which 14-year-old Suzi played bass. Managed by Quatro’s brother, they toured extensively and released singles.

She was talent-spotted by an English record producer Mickie Most, and quit the band to cross the Atlantic in 1971 for her shot at fame. This was a source of deep family resentment which, fully five decades later, gets a pretty intense airing in the new documentary by Australian director Liam Firmager.

Suzi Quatro, in trademark leather, in Sydney for a series of concerts in November 1974. Trevor Dallen

There’s a punchy scene where her family sends Quatro, by then living in England, a tape cassette for Thanksgiving. She’s expecting a homely, comforting message, but instead it’s a recording of them criticising her musicianship and generally taking her down a peg. The malice makes you squirm.

“There were five of us all in the business at one time or another and I got plucked out. So I can understand it, where it comes from,” she says. “But that was 50 years ago, get over it. And tell it to myself, get over it – because it still hurts. It’s like an open wound.”

Meanwhile, Mickie Most dressed her up in that leather catsuit and teamed her up with songwriters Nicky Chinn and Mike Chapman (an Australian), with whom she pumped out a bunch of hits. She never really made it in the States and had mixed fortunes in Britain, but through the '70s and early '80s she was big in Europe – and absolutely massive in Australia.

Quatro doesn’t really have a theory about why Australians are so receptive. I speculate that although Australia is considered a bit of a macho place, there's a distinctive strain of toughness in the female side of our national psyche. Perhaps we just better understand this ballsy, brash, bass-playing rocker?

She’s not sure. “Maybe. It’s hard to understand where it comes from. I was huge in Japan too, which is the opposite. I mean, women walk behind – give me a break, can you ever see me doing that?”

As she recorded, and toured, and recorded, and toured, and as her fame grew, Little Suzi learned to be Suzi Quatro – the pin-up on a million bedroom walls, the actress in Happy Days, the rock star she’d always wanted to be.

I wasn’t really a drugs and drinks person whatsoever. I never drink when I go on stage, not a drop. — Suzi Quatro

But the story doesn’t include the standard Hollywood-style narrative of wealth and fame become intoxicating, overwhelming, and ending up in moral or financial ruin.

“I wasn’t really a drugs and drinks person whatsoever. I never drink when I go on stage, not a drop. Afterwards I’ll have a glass of something, sure, because you’re high as a kite,” she says.

“This is what has saved me all these years. I go on the road and I do what I do, and then I come back. My husband always says, ‘You’re the wild one on stage and the mild one off’.”

Here’s the Gemini, then: manic energy on stage, the very essence of a rock n’roll wild child; twinned with beatific calm off stage, the poetry-writing mother of two who lives a quiet rural life.

But as we work through our main meal – a very decent halibut for me, aubergine for Quatro – she also goes on to describe herself another way, in which she’s not at all bifurcated. In this version, the stage Suzi, while high-octane, is the real Suzi.

“There are two people, because there’s a performer, naturally there’s a performer, so there’s a private person as well. But pretty much what you see is what you get. Here I am. I go on stage, I do what I do, that’s a huge part of me, I come off stage and here I am.”

Advertisement

In this vein, she talks a lot about truth, about being true to yourself, and about showing people your real self, about being accessible to her admirers.

She doesn't do the wig, cap and sunglasses when out shopping, and is actually happy when fans approach her to say hi. And on tour, people have paid to see her so she’ll “go out there and be good”: “I’ve got to entertain as best I can. You get all of me on stage, I give it all.”

I don’t do gender, I believe in being whoever you are, whoever that may be. Don’t put any limits on me. — Suzi Quatro

This is certainly the impression I’m getting. She knows exactly who she is, and she is completely candid.

Early days in leather.

We talk about a new film she’s writing that dramatises her life story – still picking at that scab of family rupture. We talk about her new album, instigated by her guitar-playing son, who took her back to her hard-rock roots (“he pushed my Suzi Quatro buttons”). And we talk about what it’s like to tour, and how every audience asks something slightly different of her.

Of course she’s been interviewed 10,000 times, but she seems genuine and authentic. You get the same sense from the new documentary. By the end of it, you have a real sense of who she is, and why she matters.

As the film’s promo says: “In 1973, there were almost no women in rock, and absolutely none who played bass and sang lead vocals and led the band and rocked out … rewriting the rule book for the expected image of women in rock and roll.”

She doesn’t don the cloak of feminist icon though. “I don’t do gender, I believe in being whoever you are, whoever that may be. It doesn’t matter, male, female, strong, weak ... Don’t put any limits on me, I’m allowed to be who I am.”

I’ve ordered a cheese platter. But she’s had a long day – she wants to get home and get ready to fly out to Australia the next day. Does touring take it out of you as you get older?

“I don’t even think about it. My husband always says, after a show, ‘you’re not even out of breath’. And I’m running on the stage with a bass guitar and a leather suit on. I guess I’ve trained a long time.”

Quatro has lived in the UK for decades, but tours Australia often. Domenico Pugliese

Is it still as fun as it used to be? “More so, because I don’t feel any pressure at all to be a certain kind of Suzi Quatro. I can go out there, I can talk to the audience, show them a picture, tell a joke, do this, whatever I do. So I can show them the whole rainbow.”

Now it’s definitely time to hit the road. “Did you get everything you need, picture-wise?” she asks the photographer, ever the solicitous professional. “I always try to give everybody their time.”

description: The iconic bass player, now almost 70, has a new album, is touring Australia, and is the subject of an imminent documentary. It's all in a day's work.
